sections: Good things are happening! States are taking on the fossil fuel industry through a plastics investigation, a ban on fossil fuels in new buildings, and by challenging the crypto industry’s ambitions to repurpose power plants for bitcoin mining. Meanwhile, teachers in Oakland took a risk by walking off the job to protest the closure of public schools. And you can pitch in to send Starbucks and Amazon workers to a labor conference.
All this and much more in this week’s edition of You Love To See It, exclusively for supporting subscribers below.

“Enough is enough,” Bonta said in a statement announcing the investigation. “For more than half a century, the plastics industry has engaged in an aggressive campaign to deceive the public, perpetuating a myth that recycling can solve the plastics crisis. OAKLAND TEACHERS WALK OUT TO DEFEND PUBLIC EDUCATION
3,000 teachers and other public school workers

off the job in Oakland on Friday for a one-day strike over plans by the city’s school board to close a dozen schools over the next two years. What’s most impressive about this job action is that the teachers did it in the face of a pledge by the school board that they would seek to find the job action illegal.

More importantly, they sought to make the day as fun as possible for kids out of school, inviting community members to a block party at Oakland’s Lake Merritt to celebrate the defense of public education.

There’s a rule in new labor organizing that when the organizing committee is happy and feeling good — even in the face of overwhelming adversity — you’re going to win. Kudos to Oakland educators on embodying that principle.

Twitter feed being the equivalent of a sage cleanse of our collective timelines. In Augusta, Georgia, Starbucks workers on Thursday won — via a vote of 25-5 — the first union Starbucks in the Peach State. The day before, the first Starbucks store in Wisconsin went union. out of 44 union elections, despite Starbucks spending $500 an hour on the anti-union law firm Littler Mendelson.
